The terms of their divorce settlement remain private, but it's possible the agreement includes other forms of compensation for MacKenzie Bezos.

As Earth revolves around the sun, it encounters cosmic debris throughout the year, leading to spectacular meteor showers that illuminate the night sky from dusk till dawn. One notable upcoming shower is the Lyrids, active from April 16 to 28, with its peak on Sunday night into Monday morning, although the moon may hinder viewing this year. Ancient Chinese astronomers documented their observations of these bursts of light, dating back over 2,700 years. Lyrid meteorites streak across the sky at approximately 107,000 miles per hour, exploding about 55 miles up in the atmosphere. The Lyrids shower originates from Comet Thatcher, which takes 415 years to complete its orbit around the sun. Comet Thatcher's last visit was in 1861, and its next approach will be in 2276. Meteor showers often result from icy comets' leftovers crashing into Earth's atmosphere, where small particles of debris pierce the sky at incredible speeds, creating a spectacular display of celestial fireworks. Comets are essentially dirty snowballs that leave behind a trail of rocks and ice as they travel through the solar system, and this dusty trail lingers in space, awaiting Earth's encounter.

San Francisco - The New York State attorney general's office is poised to launch an investigation into Facebook's unauthorized collection of over 1.5 million users' email address books. The inquiry focuses on a practice uncovered in April, where Facebook gathered the email contact lists of new users who signed up for the platform after 2016. These lists were used to refine Facebook's ad-targeting algorithms and other social connections across the network. The investigation was officially confirmed by the attorney general's office late Thursday afternoon. "Facebook has consistently disregarded consumers' privacy while profiting from exploiting their personal data," said New York Attorney General Letitia James in a statement. "It's time Facebook is held accountable for its handling of consumers' personal information."

While some parasites are notorious for their sinister effects, others play a vital role in their ecosystems. For example, the fungus Cordyceps manipulates ants into committing suicide, while Toxoplasma gondii eliminates a mouse's fear of cats. In contrast, the Sacculina carcini barnacle takes a drastic approach, castrating crabs and transforming them into "zombie" slaves that care for its young.

In a surprising twist, some parasites can even benefit their hosts. In eastern North America, wood-eating beetles infected with a parasitic worm have their insides resemble a plate of moving spaghetti. Despite this, the infected beetles tend to be larger and eat more than their uninfected counterparts, according to a recent study published in Biology Letters. This increased consumption may actually aid the forest cycle nutrients more efficiently, benefiting the entire ecosystem.

The study's lead researcher, Andy Davis, an ecologist at the University of Georgia, notes that everything is interconnected in the natural world. "Here's a case where a small bug in the forest is doing something important, and then there's another bug that lives inside that bug that's doing something important too," he says.

James Bennet, editorial page editor of The New York Times, has announced he will step back from covering the 2020 presidential election after his brother Michael Bennet's (D-Colo.) candidacy announcement. This move is expected, given James Bennet's potential succession to Dean Baquet as executive editor. With over a decade in the Senate, Michael Bennet had previously expressed interest in a presidential bid. It's unusual for a newspaper's Opinion section head to disengage from a dominant topic. James Bennet's moratorium applies to all opinion pieces, including Op-Eds, columns, editorials, and articles on presidential candidates or campaign issues. The Times has appointed Kathleen Kingsbury and James Dao to share responsibilities for political coverage, which will remain in place as long as Michael Bennet remains a candidate.

Throughout the year, Earth's orbit around the sun brings it into contact with streams of cosmic debris. This debris can result in spectacular meteor showers that illuminate the night sky from dusk to dawn, offering a rare chance to catch a glimpse if you're fortunate. The next notable shower is the Eta Aquariids, active from April 19 to May 28, with a peak around May 5-6. With the moon approaching new, clear skies could provide optimal viewing conditions. The Eta Aquariids are one of two meteor showers linked to Halley's comet, with its sister shower, the Orionids, peaking in October. The Eta Aquariids are notable for their exceptional speed, reaching approximately 148,000 miles per hour, making them one of the fastest meteor showers. The display is more prominent in the Southern Hemisphere, where observers can expect to see 20-30 meteors per hour during the peak. In contrast, the Northern Hemisphere tends to see about half as many.

When you spot a meteor shower, you're typically witnessing the remnants of an icy comet colliding with Earth's atmosphere. Comets, often referred to as "dirty snowballs," leave behind a trail of rocky and icy debris as they travel through the solar system. This debris lingers in space long after the comet has passed, and when Earth encounters these cascades, the small particles – sometimes as small as grains of sand – enter the atmosphere at incredible speeds, producing a breathtaking celestial display.

A study warns that climate change and rising sea levels pose a significant threat to one of the world's last and largest tiger habitats. The report highlights that nearly 500,000 land species are at risk of extinction due to threats to their natural habitats. The Sundarbans, a 4,000-square-mile region in Bangladesh and India, is home to the world's largest mangrove forest and a diverse ecosystem that supports hundreds of animal species, including the endangered Bengal tiger. However, 70% of the region is only a few feet above sea level, making it extremely vulnerable to climate change impacts. Researchers predict that the warming planet will decimate the few hundred Bengal tigers remaining in the region. By 2070, the study concludes that there will be no suitable tiger habitats remaining in the Bangladesh Sundarbans. Climate change has already had a devastating impact on the world's endangered mammals, with a recent study finding that it has harmed almost half of them. The new report's lead author and colleagues examined the risks to the tiger population beyond sea level rise, which accounted for only 5.4-11.3% of the projected habitat loss in 2050 and 2070. They found that other climate-related factors were more significant threats to the Sundarbans' tigers. Habitat loss, hunting, and the illegal trade of animal parts have contributed to the global tiger population decline since the early 1900s. A recent study has discovered that the Bangladesh Sundarbans will likely experience a decline in its population due to an increase in extreme weather events and changes in vegetation. As the Sundarbans flood, the likelihood of conflicts between humans and tigers will rise. The situation could worsen significantly if a cyclone hits, a disease outbreak occurs, or a food shortage develops. If greenhouse gas emissions continue to rise at their current rate, the Earth's atmosphere will warm by as much as 2.7 degrees Fahrenheit above preindustrial levels by 2040.

Imagine a creature with dinosaur-like features, and you might not envision a bat. However, a team of Chinese paleontologists has made a groundbreaking find that could alter your perception. They've unearthed a dinosaur, Ambopteryx longibrachium, with fleshy wings similar to a bat's, which existed around 163 million years ago. Initially, paleontologist Min Wang believed it was a bird due to its long forelimbs, a characteristic shared by modern birds. Yet, as his team excavated the fossil over a year, distinctly dinosaurian traits became apparent, including long fingers unique to dinosaurs.

About 50 years ago, astronauts on the Apollo mission deployed temporary seismometers on the lunar surface, revealing a surprisingly dynamic moon with diverse quake types. Some quakes were likely caused by Earth's gravitational pull, while others were triggered by meteorite impacts or temperature-driven surface expansion and contraction every two weeks. Shallow moonquakes occurring just a few miles beneath the surface remained unexplained until a recent study in Nature Geoscience attributed them to a combination of internal heat escape and Earth's gravitational pull, triggering movements along numerous young faults. This discovery suggests that the moon is still tectonically active, raising concerns about shallow moonquakes at future lunar bases and sparking questions about the moon's evolution, particularly given its small size and assumption of internal heat escape. Despite its small size, the moon's internal heat appears to still be driving geological activity, contradicting expectations.

Conde Nast has sold Golf Digest to Discovery Inc., the companies announced, as the publisher streamlines its portfolio amid financial struggles. The reported sale price is $35 million, but the terms remain undisclosed. Discovery plans to retain Golf Digest's editorial team, including Editor-in-Chief Jerry Tarde, and will continue publishing the print magazine. Tarde will oversee the global strategy and content for Discovery Golf, which includes GolfTV, a digital platform live-streaming professional golf tournaments worldwide. Tarde expressed optimism about the partnership, citing the benefits of Discovery's global reach and platform distribution, combined with the PGA Tour's brand, for golf and golfers worldwide.

If you've ever taken a large bite of wasabi, you're familiar with the intense, spreading sensation that seeps into your scalp. You're not alone in your distress - many animals share your aversion to the spicy condiment. The culprit behind wasabi's sinus-clearing properties is a chemical compound called allyl isothiocyanate, which actively disrupts proteins within cells. Flies, flatworms, mice, and wolf spiders all shun this compound, and nearly every animal will do the same. However, there is one notable exception: the highveld mole rat, a rodent native to South Africa, is completely immune to the substance. A recent study published in Science showcased the rodent's remarkable resistance to allyl isothiocyanate. The findings highlight the significance of studying naturally occurring differences in pain sensitivity, and may ultimately lead to more effective pain treatment in humans.

The House has recently passed a retirement bill with a significant bipartisan majority, encompassing a range of provisions that will impact various groups of American savers and retirees. The legislation makes several key changes, with one notable provision allowing employers to offer complex annuity products as part of their retirement plans. The bill's significant changes include:

* Allowing workers to contribute to individual retirement accounts without age restrictions, rather than being limited to age 70 1/2.
* Increasing the age at which individuals must begin taking withdrawals from their Individual Retirement Accounts (IRAs) to 72, up from 70 1/2.
* Permitting penalty-free withdrawals from retirement plans to cover expenses related to the birth or adoption of a child.

Jeffrey Goldberg, editor-in-chief of The Atlantic, drew criticism after confessing that it's challenging to assign cover stories to writers outside of white males. In a Nieman Lab interview, Goldberg revealed that writing a 10,000-word cover story is a daunting task, and only a select group of white male journalists possess the necessary skills. Of The Atlantic's 15 most recent cover stories, 11 were penned by men. Goldberg proposed identifying and mentoring new writers, but acknowledged that this approach may not always yield successful results. His comments sparked widespread criticism, with many accusing him of undervaluing underrepresented writers. The article's length sparked a lively Twitter discussion, with journalists chiming in. Margaret Sullivan joked about her own writing limitations, saying she aspires to write 1,200 words but tops out at 850. Andi Zeisler quipped, "Has anyone informed Jeffrey Goldberg about women who write books?"

Mitchel R. Levitas, a celebrated journalist, passed away at his home in New Marlborough, Massachusetts, on Saturday at the age of 89. He succumbed to Alzheimer's disease, which was complicated by pneumonia, according to his son Daniel. Levitas held influential positions at The New York Times for nearly four decades, overseeing the paper's metropolitan coverage and editing various sections. Born and raised in New York City, Levitas graduated from the city's public schools and colleges before joining The New York Times in 1965 as a writer and editor. He retired in 2002 after 37 years with the paper, having served as editorial director of book development. Levitas continued to work as a consultant for the book development office until 2014. Known to his colleagues as Mike, Levitas was a meticulous editor with a keen eye for detail. As an assistant metropolitan editor, he played a crucial role in assigning a reporter to investigate the authenticity of "The Last Testament of Lucky Luciano."

CBS's "Late Show with Stephen Colbert" is a highly popular program on the network. Despite prolonged negotiations, CBS and AT&T were unable to reach a contract agreement by the Saturday deadline. Consequently, CBS went dark for over 6.5 million AT&T customers early Saturday morning, impacting its satellite service DirecTV, landline-delivered U-verse, and live streaming product DirecTV Now. The blackout affected customers in at least 14 major markets, including New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, and San Francisco. The network, carried in approximately 119 million homes across the country, lost tens of millions of dollars in monthly revenue. CBS and AT&T had been at odds over pricing and streaming rights, with CBS refusing to agree to terms that would devalue its popular programming. AT&T accused CBS of being a repeat blackout offender and demanded a more reasonable fee structure. CBS seeks an increase in retransmission consent fees, last negotiated in 2012. While CBS is available for free over the air, it also sells its rights to pay-TV operators like AT&T. According to sources, CBS received $2 per AT&T subscriber monthly and now seeks a fee in the range of $3.

On July 21, 1969, at 2:56 a.m. Coordinated Universal Time, humans achieved a groundbreaking feat by landing on another planet for the first time. This pivotal moment captivated millions worldwide, who watched live on television and listened on the radio. As people gazed up at the moon and their own Earth, a shared perspective emerged. For most people alive today, the Apollo 11 mission is a nostalgic memory, predating their birth. Even for those who recall the event, it's easy to overlook that the Apollo program unfolded during a tumultuous period in American history, when many Americans prioritized other pressing issues over space exploration. Despite skepticism, the mission's success became synonymous with humanity's potential, inspiring the notion that if we could put a man on the moon, we could accomplish anything. To commemorate this complex history and The New York Times' coverage, the science desk has been publishing a series of articles, essays, photo galleries, and a poem throughout the month, reflecting on the legacy of Apollo 11 and the promise and challenges of a new era of space exploration.

San Francisco - Food delivery startup DoorDash announced it's acquiring Caviar, a rival service, for $410 million, further intensifying the competitive food delivery landscape. DoorDash is purchasing Caviar from Square, a payments company that has owned it since 2014. Caviar operates in 15 cities, primarily offering upscale restaurant food in urban areas. According to DoorDash CEO Tony Xu, Caviar's selection of higher-end restaurants in cities complements DoorDash's offerings, which focus on chain restaurants in suburban areas. Xu described his conversation with Square's CEO Jack Dorsey about the potential deal as brief. The food delivery market has grown increasingly competitive, with DoorDash, Postmates, GrubHub, and Uber Eats vying for customers, drivers, and restaurant clients. The intense competition has been fueled by Uber's initial public offering in May and the potential IPO of Postmates, which filed confidentially with the Securities and Exchange Commission in February but has not yet set a date for its listing.

Sponges, classified as poriferans, are defined by their soft, sedentary nature and numerous pores. Comb jellies, also known as ctenophores, are gelatinous, feathery creatures with cilia resembling combs. Researchers have been debating the closest relative to the first animal to evolve for a decade. The latest analysis indicates that sponges are the closest living relatives of the earliest animal, although this conclusion may be disputed. All animals, from sponges and comb jellies to humans and other mammals, share fundamental characteristics such as multicellularity, nucleated cells, and the ability to consume food. All animals are descended from a common ocean-dwelling ancestor that lived at least 550 million years ago and shared these characteristics. The appearance and lifestyle of the first animal remain unclear. To understand the origins of the animal kingdom, researchers study existing species to infer the common ancestor's characteristics. By comparing modern animals, we can reconstruct what the ancestor was like, including its complexity, genes, and traits.

"Stay up to date with space and astronomy events by setting calendar reminders. Witnessing a meteor shower means seeing the remnants of a comet's icy trail as it enters Earth's atmosphere. Comets are made up of dirty snowballs that release rocks and ice as they travel through the solar system. The trail lingers in space and when Earth encounters it, small particles burn up, creating a spectacular display. You're seeing the remnants of the comet's previous passes, not its most recent orbit. For the best view, find a spot with a clear view of the night sky, ideally with dark skies, away from city lights and traffic. Look for a spot with a wide, unobstructed view to maximize your chances of spotting the show. Meteor showers are typically visible for a set period, peaking in visibility from dusk to dawn on specific days. The peak times vary, with some lasting only a few hours and others several nights. The showers tend to be most visible after midnight and before dawn. For the best viewing experience, use your naked eye. When using binoculars or telescopes, spend around 30 minutes in the dark to adjust your eyes. Be aware that moonlight and inclement weather can sometimes obscure celestial events. If this happens, consider alternative options like NASA and Slooh's meteor livestreams."

In 1995, WNYC, New York's public radio station, had a new boss, with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in office, and a monthly audience of around one million listeners and an operating budget of $8 million. Since then, New York Public Radio, WNYC's parent organization, has expanded to become a prominent public media entity, boasting a budget of $97 million, nationally syndicated radio programs, and popular podcasts like "2 Dope Queens" and "Trump, Inc.". The organization claims its various broadcast and online platforms now attract 24 million people. After nearly a quarter-century, New York Public Radio has welcomed a new leader. The nonprofit group announced on Wednesday that Goli Sheikholeslami, who has led Chicago Public Media and WBEZ since 2014, and has held executive positions at The Washington Post and Conde Nast, will become the organization's new chief executive. She is set to start her new role in New York in October.

Google has resolved a dispute with the National Labor Relations Board over allegations from multiple employees that the company silenced dissent, including a conservative who was allegedly terminated for speaking out. As part of the agreement, Google will inform employees about their federal rights, including the freedom to discuss workplace conditions, and guarantee they won't be retaliated against for exercising those rights. Google will post a notice reminding employees of their National Labor Relations Act rights and clarifying that workplace policies do not prohibit discussing issues. The settlement awaits NLRB approval, with a regional director already indicating her approval.

Radar technology's enhanced efficiency may contribute to the impression that more insects are present, whether it's a swarm of ladybugs in California or a billion hoverflies in England. On Monday, meteorologist Doug Kahn from the National Weather Service in Cleveland detected multiple blue masses moving and expanding on the radar over Ohio, which weren't storm clouds or a weather system, but a massive swarm of dragonflies. Kahn estimated there were millions of them, explaining why they were so prominent on the radar. The Weather Service employs a dual-polarization radar that generates a three-dimensional-like image of the atmosphere, scanning horizontally and vertically to measure dimensions and identify airborne entities, even before they become visible to the naked eye.

"Game of Thrones" has secured the most Emmy wins for a drama series in television history, an unlikely conclusion to its final season. The HBO fantasy epic dominated the Creative Arts Emmy Awards, claiming a record 10 awards, the most for any series in the Primetime Emmys' opening ceremonies. HBO's limited series "Chernobyl" also had a successful night, taking home seven Creative Arts Emmys. Amazon's "The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel" won six awards, including honors for guest acting by Jane Lynch and Luke Kirby. In the drama guest acting categories, Cherry Jones and Bradley Whitford took home awards for their roles in Hulu's "The Handmaid's Tale". The 71st Primetime Emmy Awards honored winners in nearly 100 categories over two ceremonies, recognizing achievements in technical areas, guest acting, and other categories.

A lightning strike's typical impact is significant, but superbolts are a distinct phenomenon. Initially detected in the 1970s by satellites designed to monitor nuclear explosions, these extraordinary lightning events are thousands of times more energetic than regular lightning. Despite their extraordinary nature, the likelihood of being struck by a superbolt is extremely low. Scientists examined data from the World Wide Lightning Location Network's 80 sensors to gain a deeper understanding of where these powerful lightning strikes occur. Their findings, published in the Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres, revealed that superbolts primarily occur over open water from November to February. Dr. Robert Holzworth and his team analyzed over 1.7 billion radio-frequency observations of lightning, focusing on the most robust detections from 2010 to 2018. They identified 8,171 superbolts with energies exceeding one million Joules, which accounts for only 0.0005 percent of the total lightning recorded by the network. Superbolts are so rare that even Dr. Holzworth, a renowned expert in the field, has never witnessed one firsthand.

Apple is entering the film industry with three movies scheduled for release this fall. The company's first foray into film was made possible after acquiring the movies earlier this year. Apple plans to expand its film efforts in 2020, producing its own movies, including co-productions with independent studio A24. A24 is known for producing critically acclaimed films like "Moonlight" and "Lady Bird". The partnership between Apple and A24 was formed last year.

The first movie to be released is "Elephant Queen", a documentary narrated by Chiwetel Ejiofor, which showcases a 50-year-old elephant. It will premiere in select cities on October 18 and become available on Apple TV+ on November 1. The second movie, "Hala", is a coming-of-age drama starring Geraldine Viswanathan as a Muslim teenager. It will be released in select theaters on November 22 and debut on Apple TV+ in December. Apple acquired "Hala" after its debut at the Sundance Film Festival in February.

A Federal District Court judge in Manhattan dismissed the lawsuit on Monday. Judge J. Paul Oetken's decision stated, "The court acknowledges that the SALT cap is a distinct provision, but the states have failed to demonstrate that it exceeds Congress's authority to impose taxes." The lawsuit was joined by New Jersey, Connecticut, and Maryland. The 2017 tax law introduced a cap on state and local tax deductions, previously unlimited, to offset the cost of trillions of dollars in tax cuts. The cap and related provisions are expected to generate nearly $700 billion in revenue over the next decade, according to the Joint Committee on Taxation. Independent analyses suggest that most residents in high-tax states like New York received a modest tax cut under the 2017 law. Other provisions of the law, such as reduced marginal tax rates, offset the loss of the deduction for many families. The state and local tax issue poses a challenge for Democrats seeking to restore a tax break primarily benefiting high-income earners. Prior to the cap's implementation, households earning $200,000 or more accounted for roughly half of the nearly $600 billion in state and local tax payments deducted on federal tax returns. Democrats argue that the SALT cap unfairly penalizes states with progressive tax policies, making state and local taxes more expensive for residents. This could hinder states' ability to raise taxes, particularly on wealthy residents, and increase pressure to cut spending. The four states claimed that the SALT cap constitutes an impermissible attempt by the federal government to influence certain states' tax policies.

Julia Sigwart, an evolutionary biologist from Queen's University Belfast in Northern Ireland, links the chiton's behavior of rolling into balls to a desire to reach new locations. This behavior dates back to the time of trilobites, which went extinct around 500 million years ago. These ancient creatures curled up for protection, and the chiton, their modern equivalent, shares this ability. Despite its appearance, which resembles a flattened piece of shrimp nigiri, the chiton is a marine mollusk that clings to tidepool rocks, not dinner plates. Like trilobites, several animals, including three-banded armadillos, pill bugs, and hedgehogs, can also roll into balls. Many scientists thought conglobation was a defense mechanism against predators, but Dr. Sigwart questions this assumption, arguing that rolling into a ball wouldn't protect an animal from being swallowed whole. In lab experiments, Dr. Sigwart found that chitons roll into balls to regain their footing after losing it. Her research, published in Biology Letters, suggests that chitons can make decisions and may be more intelligent than previously thought.

We typically develop our smartphone typing skills through trial and error, as there is no universally accepted technique. Unlike typing on a typewriter or computer, where established methods exist, smartphone typing lacks a standardized approach. A recent study involving 37,000 participants found that a specific method - using two thumbs and relying on autocorrect while avoiding predictive text - yields faster typing. According to Per Ola Kristensson, this technique is essential for quick typing. The study, presented at a human-computer interaction conference in Taipei, focused on the Qwerty keyboard, originally designed to prevent mechanical jams in typewriters. Despite questions about its relevance and the emergence of alternative layouts, the Qwerty layout remains widely used.

James Murdoch, former CEO of 21st Century Fox, has acquired a minority stake in Vice Media, targeting millennials. Through Lupa Systems, his holding company, Murdoch invested in Vice as part of its Refinery29 acquisition. According to a source familiar with the matter, the investment was first reported by The Financial Times. After leaving 21st Century Fox, founded by his father Rupert Murdoch, James Murdoch established Lupa Systems. The Murdoch family sold Fox's majority assets to Disney for over $70 billion, with James receiving a $2 billion payout. Since then, he has invested in various media businesses, departing from his father's ventures. He has demonstrated less enthusiasm for traditional news ventures, the source noted.

Uber has invested heavily in Cornershop, a grocery delivery startup, to enhance its food delivery capabilities. This acquisition marks a significant shift for the company, which is seeking to broaden its scope beyond its core ride-hailing service following a tumultuous IPO in May. Despite a slowdown in its core business, Uber is prioritizing the expansion of its food and freight delivery services, as well as venturing into new markets like bicycle and scooter rentals. Cornershop, operating in Chile, Mexico, Peru, and Canada, will be integrated into Uber's platform, with plans to expand into additional markets, including the United States. "We're thrilled to collaborate with Cornershop and look forward to bringing grocery delivery to millions of consumers on the Uber platform," said Dara Khosrowshahi, Uber's CEO, in a statement.

Lyft has refocused on achieving profitability, with CEO Logan Green announcing substantial progress towards this goal. Green revealed that the company is on track to reach profitability by late 2021, excluding certain expenses. During the latest earnings call, executives reaffirmed their commitment to achieving operating profitability. The shift towards profitability comes as Lyft's losses were primarily driven by stock-based compensation costs and payroll tax expenses. Excluding these costs, Lyft's operating loss was $121.6 million for the quarter, a less severe outcome than Wall Street estimates. Lyft's stock jumped nearly 1.5 percent in after-hours trading on Wednesday. CFO Brian Roberts attributed the company's strong revenue performance, stating, "We significantly exceeded revenue expectations." Roberts also emphasized Lyft's dedication to achieving profitability by a specific date, a rare approach in the industry. Earlier this year, Lyft had predicted record losses as it prioritized growth, but the company has since adjusted its strategy in response to a shift in sentiment towards prominent tech startups.

The decision to leave the publication must have been a grueling one, considering the fragile job market in the industry. Newspapers have been struggling for over a decade, particularly in small towns and midsize cities, and digital news outlets that emerged in their wake have also shown signs of strain. In a text message, Ms. McKinney stated, "I no longer believe this company supports its writers," citing the deletion of a post acknowledging reader complaints about auto-playing ads as evidence. Investigative reporter Diana Moskovitz announced on Twitter that she had given her two weeks' notice, stating, "What happened today, and everything that led up to it, are among the reasons I decided to move on." G/O Media maintains that Deadspin is free to cover topics that may seem unrelated to sports, as long as there is a sports-related angle. Following the mass exodus, the company released a statement, saying, "They resigned and we're sorry they couldn't work within our broad coverage mandate. We're excited about Deadspin's future and will have important updates in the coming days." Deadspin has been without a full-time top editor since August, when Editor-in-Chief Megan Greenwell resigned due to undue interference from management. Greenwell is now a columnist at The New York Times. One of Deadspin's notable investigative reports was a 2013 story revealing that the feel-good story about Notre Dame star linebacker Manti Te'o was fabricated, including the claim that his long-distance girlfriend had died in a car accident. Deadspin was sold to Univision in 2016 after being acquired by Gawker Media, which was subsequently sold following a $140 million judgment against Gawker in an invasion-of-privacy lawsuit backed by Peter Thiel, a Silicon Valley billionaire.

Recent hurricanes such as Katrina, Harvey, Maria, and Dorian have caused thousands of fatalities and billions of dollars in destruction. Despite limited records dating back only a century and a half, researchers have compiled a 1,500-year history of hurricanes in the Bahamas, revealing significant fluctuations in activity over time. Compared to historical highs, recent activity in the Bahamas is relatively low, except in other parts of the Atlantic. Scientists attribute these fluctuations to changes in atmospheric and oceanic circulation, as well as volcanic activity. The destruction caused by Hurricane Dorian has sparked a "wake-up call" among researchers, highlighting the need for a deeper understanding of hurricane patterns and processes within the context of long-term history. Blue holes, formed when carbonate rock erodes and collapses, are revered for their deep, clear waters and serve as valuable repositories of scientific data. Hurricanes deposit coarse materials like sand, gravel, shells, and coral fragments into these holes, making them important keepers of the historical record.

Xerox has become synonymous with photocopying and printing, a reputation HP has also built around its printers. The company is now seeking to merge with HP, a move that follows occasional conversations about a potential business combination. HP will thoughtfully consider its options, taking deliberate and disciplined action to ensure the best interests of all shareholders are served. A merger would bring together two former industry leaders that have faced significant challenges in recent years, as demand for printed documents and ink has decreased.

Facebook is introducing a data portability tool in Ireland, enabling users to transfer photos and videos from Facebook to Google Photos. The move comes in response to European privacy laws and regulatory criticism of Facebook's dominance over user data. Critics argue the initiative doesn't go far enough, citing Facebook's control over user data and the competitive imbalance it creates for rivals. Facebook's dominance has historically made it difficult for users to leave the platform due to the complexity of transferring content and data. Authorities are debating the potential benefits of enabling companies to allow users to take their content and data to other services, promoting more competition.

During the Cretaceous period, the tooth fairy would have been inundated with dinosaur teeth. Unlike humans, who lose only one set of teeth, dinosaurs frequently shed tens or hundreds of sets due to their unique dental habits. Herbivorous dinosaurs, which needed to chew through tough plant material, often replaced their teeth frequently. However, researchers were surprised to discover that a carnivorous dinosaur replaced its teeth even more frequently than some herbivores. The dinosaur's habit of chewing on its prey's bones may have contributed to its rapid tooth replacement rate, scientists hypothesized. The findings were published in the journal PLoS One and focused on several meat-eating dinosaurs, with Majungasaurus crenatissimus emerging as the star of the study. This 20-foot-long apex predator, which lived on Madagascar around 70 million years ago, left behind a remarkable fossil record, including several complete skeletons, hundreds of fragmentary skeletons, and tens of thousands of shed teeth. "This is quite unusual," said Michael D. D'Emic, a vertebrate paleontologist at Adelphi University, who led the study.

For centuries, scientists, including Darwin, have grappled with the enigma: despite being nutrient-poor, tropical waters remain remarkably clear. However, coral reefs thrive, supporting a staggering quarter of all known species on Earth. The solution to this paradox lies partly with sugar. We commonly assume the ocean is salty, but it also harbors microscopic morsels of sugars and carbohydrates, known as dissolved organic matter. This dissolved substance accounts for most of the ocean's organic material and is particularly prevalent near coral reefs. "Consider all these sugars dissolved in the ocean," said Michelle Achlatis, a researcher at the California Academy of Sciences. "If no one can utilize them, they might as well not exist." This filter-feeding sponge, found on coral reefs in the Indian and Pacific Oceans, extracts tiny plankton as it floats in the water, using its filtering cells to draw sugars from the seawater.

Initially, it's clear that this new job is not the solution people had hoped for. Instead of offering a safer alternative to the mine, it presents a fundamentally different type of employment. Although the mine was hazardous, it provided secure employment with benefits. In contrast, the warehouse job is precarious, lacking benefits, a full-time contract, and guarantees of a pension, sick pay, or holiday pay. Moreover, workers are paid at or below the minimum wage. A government inquiry into the warehouse's practices several years ago uncovered disturbing instances of employees being penalized for taking breaks, including a woman who was so fearful of job loss that she gave birth in the warehouse and left her newborn in a bathroom.

Uber is reportedly close to finalizing a deal to sell its Indian food delivery arm, Uber Eats, to Zomato, a local food delivery service, for $400 million. The proposed sale aims to curb losses and is part of the company's efforts to streamline operations and demonstrate profitability to investors. CEO Dara Khosrowshahi has been working to divest money-losing ventures, including Uber Eats' Indian business, to clean up the company's balance sheet and appease investors.

A new California state law, intended to enhance working conditions for contractors at companies like Uber and Lyft, is unexpectedly resulting in the loss of regular writing assignments for over 200 bloggers in the state. As a consequence, Vox Media has announced the elimination of 200 freelance positions at its sports outlet, SB Nation, effective immediately. The affected writers are regular contributors to 25 SB Nation blogs focused on California teams, including Golden State of Mind, Conquest Chronicles, and True Blue LA. Many of these writers have been producing dozens of posts annually for minimal compensation, according to a related lawsuit. The law, set to take effect on January 1, poses a significant challenge for SB Nation, as it restricts contractors from submitting more than 35 written content pieces per year.

To share a specific album with a family group, start by selecting and organizing the photos you want to share into that album. If you have automatic backups enabled on your device, the photos are already stored in your Google Account's online storage space. Alternatively, manually upload the selected photos you want to share online. If you have a folder of images on your computer, log in to the website, drag the pictures onto the browser window, or click the Upload button and navigate to the folder to add them.

The fate of ABC's "Roseanne" reboot remains uncertain, sparking controversy even before its revival. At a press event in Pasadena, California, on Monday, Roseanne Barr faced repeated questions about her support for President Trump and that of her character, just two months ahead of the show's revival. While Barr clarified she wasn't a Trump supporter, she argued her character's stance in the reboot reflected the nation's deep divisions. "I've always aimed to portray a genuine representation of our society," Barr said. "Half the country voted for him, half didn't. This is a realistic portrayal."

Actress and activist Rose McGowan is set to star in a documentary series called "Citizen Rose", which premieres on E! later this month. The series promises an unfiltered look into McGowan's life, starting with a two-hour episode on January 30 and continuing with four more installments in the spring. McGowan became involved in September, after a New York Times story revealed her settlement agreement with Harvey Weinstein, whom she accused of sexual assault. Andrea Metz, an executive producer, was convinced by McGowan's pitch, which she recalled as "It'll be worth it, I promise." Filming began in September and will incorporate footage recorded by McGowan over the past three years. As the #MeToo movement gained momentum, McGowan became a prominent voice advocating for women who have been victims of sexual harassment and abuse. She has publicly condemned men accused of sexual misconduct and criticized those who have not been outspoken enough. McGowan's online following, known as the #RoseArmy, has grown significantly since the Weinstein scandal broke. In a recent Twitter rant, McGowan criticized what she saw as "Hollywood fakery" during the Golden Globes ceremony. McGowan expressed her desire to engage in meaningful conversations with the world, emulating Gertrude Stein, but wanted to do so in a more public setting. E! has had a mixed track record with its topical programming, with shows like "I Am Cait" and "Mariah's World" experiencing lackluster ratings. McGowan is unapologetic about her show's genre, stating, "I'm okay with calling this reality TV because this is my story."

For nearly a decade, The Awl has been urging readers to "Be Less Stupid" through thoughtful coverage of unconventional topics. Editors have cautioned against the vast internet landscape, advocating intelligence in online navigation. Despite efforts to uphold their motto, the editors of The Awl and its sister site, The Hairpin, announced that the curtain will soon come down. Editorial operations will cease at the end of January. The closures mark another setback for independent publishers, which have long faced challenges in competing with larger entities. The Awl's publisher attributed the decision to close to a steady decline in direct sales. The Awl reflected on its efforts to build a better internet, acknowledging that it did not always succeed but striving to do so with integrity. The site proudly declared that its greatest achievement was the quality and passion of its audience, which it believed was unparalleled.

"Despite significant hurdles and a prolonged timeline, most attempts to revive net neutrality are underway. Notably, Montana's Governor Steve Bullock has taken a unique approach. By issuing an executive order, he has introduced net neutrality regulations to a substantial portion of the state. The order prohibits internet service providers with state government contracts from blocking or charging extra for faster website access to any customer in the state. Major providers such as Charter, CenturyLink, AT&T, and Verizon, which currently hold government contracts in Montana, will be subject to the new requirements. The new rules will apply to all new and renewed contracts signed after July 1, 2018."

"I'm new to Instagram and looking to discover new accounts to follow. In addition to Facebook friends, how can I find new users? To do so, utilize Instagram's search function, similar to Twitter and LinkedIn. Access the search page by tapping the magnifying glass icon in the toolbar, where you can search for individuals, hashtags, or locations. The search results will feature top accounts. Hashtags are labels that start with "#" and categorize posts, making them easier to find. The hashtag page showcases all posts with the same tag."

"A revealing expose of the underground drug market, Silk Road, has sparked concerns that valuable content could vanish from the internet if Gawker and L.A. Weekly's wealthy owners decide to remove it. To mitigate this risk, the Freedom of the Press Foundation will start archiving vulnerable online content, beginning with the two publications. The organization, which advocates for and defends adversarial journalism, aims to shield publications from the 'billionaire problem' - the ability of wealthy individuals to acquire and silence news outlets."

A major development unfolded on Thursday in the ongoing saga surrounding the future of the $37 billion Redstone media empire, as CBS Corporation and Viacom announced plans to revive a stalled merger attempt from over a year ago. In a joint statement, CBS and Viacom revealed that their boards have established independent committees to evaluate the feasibility of a combination, but emphasized that a deal is not yet certain. The companies' decision to re-examine a potential merger comes as they acknowledge the need to grow to remain competitive in the rapidly evolving media landscape, where scale is increasingly vital. This shift in strategy likely stems from recent industry trends, including Disney's acquisition of 21st Century Fox and AT&T's pursuit of Time Warner for $85.4 billion. Moreover, traditional media companies are facing increased competition from technology giants like Apple and Facebook, which have expanded into the entertainment sector.

HBO is teaming up with the hosts of popular podcast "Pod Save America" to create hour-long TV specials later this year. This move follows the success of HBO's initial four specials featuring Jessica Williams and Phoebe Robinson, hosts of "2 Dope Queens", which garnered positive reviews and included an interview with Jon Stewart. "Pod Save America", hosted by Jon Favreau, Jon Lovett, Dan Pfeiffer, and Tommy Vietor, has become a staple for liberal Americans since the Trump era. Initially produced as a podcast called "Keepin' It 1600" for Bill Simmons's website The Ringer during the 2016 campaign, the show continued after the election due to its popularity. With Donald Trump's presidency altering the media landscape, "Pod Save America" now averages around 1.5 million listeners per episode. HBO has partnered with Crooked Media, founded by Favreau, Lovett, and Vietor, to produce the TV specials.

Security experts have uncovered evidence that the attack was planned as far back as late 2017. The attack was designed to disrupt the Pyeongchang Games or convey a political message, targeting the Pyeongchang Organizing Committee. Cisco's Talos threat intelligence division discovered that the malware was programmed to destroy the host computer and leave it offline, with no intention of making it usable. However, the attackers halted the destruction, erasing only backup files on Windows machines, allowing responders to reboot and repair the damage. Talos researchers are puzzled by this decision, with Craig Williams questioning, "Why did they hold back?" and speculating that it may be a political message implying the attackers could have caused more harm. Other internet security companies, including CrowdStrike, have reached similar conclusions, with Adam Meyers revealing that the destructive payload was constructed on December 27 at 11:39 a.m. Coordinated Universal Time, equivalent to 6:39 a.m. Eastern Time, 2:39 p.m. in Moscow, and 8:39 p.m. in South Korea.

"Microsoft Office can be used on a Chromebook, but not the traditional Windows or Mac versions. Newer Chromebook models that support Google Play store downloads can run Microsoft's Office apps for Android devices, which are free for devices with screens under 10.1 inches and require a Microsoft account for creation and editing. For larger screens, a paid subscription to Microsoft's Office 365 service, starting at $7 per month, is necessary."

ABC executives expressed concerns before the ceremony, urging Oscar winners to avoid controversial political speeches and maintain a lighthearted tone. The ceremony largely sidestepped industry concerns about the Trump administration, diverging from the politics-heavy Golden Globes and Emmys. However, the show did acknowledge the #MeToo and Time's Up movements. TV executives often blame poor ratings on a lackluster lineup of performers or movies. In contrast, "The Shape of Water" shattered records with $57.4 million in ticket sales, making it the biggest best picture winner in five years. Live award show ratings have been plummeting over the past six months, with the Grammys experiencing a 25% decline in viewership in January and the Screen Actors Guild Awards experiencing a 30% drop. This trend is consistent across most live events, including the Super Bowl and the Olympics, which also saw significant declines in viewership this year.

Russ Solomon, who left this world at 92, forged a lasting legacy as the visionary behind Tower Records, a treasured music haven. With its instantly recognizable color palette and slogan, Tower Records ruled the retail music landscape before the digital age. At its zenith, the chain boasted over 200 stores across 15 countries, with annual sales exceeding $1 billion. Solomon's journey began at his father's Sacramento drugstore, where he sold used jukebox records as a teenager. From there, he built a retail empire celebrated for its vast music selection and vibrant culture. Tower Records' employees were passionate music enthusiasts, and the stores became gathering places for fans. The Sunset Boulevard and Broadway locations became popular tourist attractions, drawing celebrity devotees like Bruce Springsteen and Bette Midler. Elton John, Tower Records' most ardent patron, often visited the Hollywood store early in the morning. A 2015 documentary features footage of John browsing the aisles and purchasing vinyl records in the 1970s. Solomon's reliance on debt to fuel Tower's expansion ultimately became a crushing burden on the company's finances. The decline of the music industry, exacerbated by online piracy, also took a devastating toll on Tower Records. The company suffered significant losses, including $10 million in 2000 and $90 million in 2001. In 2004, Tower Records' parent company filed for bankruptcy, and two years later, the company closed its 89 American stores after liquidation sales. Outside the first store in Sacramento, employees left a poignant message: "All things must pass." A Tower Records store near Lincoln Center in New York was bustling with shoppers seeking out final deals in October 2006. Physical album sales in the United States plummeted from 785 million in 2000 to 103 million in the most recent year, as music consumption shifted towards digital formats.

I'm seeking a lightweight laptop that still accommodates CDs and DVDs, which seem to be relics of the past. Do modern computers still support disc usage? 

In designing modern laptops, manufacturers have increasingly omitted disc drives, floppy drives, Ethernet jacks, and other outdated features, as cloud servers and wireless networks have become the norm for data storage and internet connections. The pursuit of smaller, lighter laptops with ample space for rechargeable batteries has also led to the removal of these once-standard computer components.

However, it's still feasible to use discs with these laptops. You can choose external hardware to accomplish this. Note that some newer laptop models may only have USB-C ports, so ensure you know what type of connectors are compatible with the laptop you're planning to purchase. If your preferred disc drive model doesn't match your laptop's connector, you can always acquire an adapter.

In the damp soil of Singapore's last remaining intact forests, peculiar egg-shaped heads of carnivorous creatures burst forth, belching, singing, or screaming "Feed me Seymour." This unusual Nepenthes ampullaria, native to Southeast Asia and the Malay Peninsula, is home to the worm larva of Xenoplatyura beaveri, a fungus gnat that develops inside the plant's mouth. As the gnat matures, it resembles a mosquito with impressive biceps. The unlikely duo shares a peculiar bond, where the plant provides a safe haven for the gnat larva to feed and develop, while the larva builds a web, captures insects, and deposits waste into the plant's pitcher, which feeds on these nutrients. This unusual arrangement exemplifies mutualism, a concept explored in a recent Biology Letters study. Researchers have simulated this insect-plant interaction in laboratory experiments, finding that cohabitation may have benefits for these obscure organisms. The study of tiny pitcher plant communities may uncover secrets about plant and insect life, revealing intricate relationships in the natural world.

The menu bar on my Mac has become cluttered with icons I rarely use and find distracting. Can I get rid of them? Most icons on the right side of the Mac's menu bar, known as "status icons," can be removed, rearranged, or restored to suit personal taste. These icons offer quick access to settings and third-party apps. Typically, Spotlight search, Siri, and the Mac's Notifications Center occupy the far right side of the menu bar. You can remove unwanted menu-bar icons in two ways. When you click on a status icon and open the app's settings, you might find a toggle to disable the menu-bar display. You can always restore the icon in the program's settings if you change your mind later.

To use picture-in-picture video with Safari on a Mac, you'll need macOS Sierra or later. This feature allows you to watch a video in a floating window while keeping other pages and programs open on your desktop. Picture-in-picture mode is supported in Safari for videos on websites that use HTML 5 playback, such as Vimeo and YouTube, as well as videos from Apple's iTunes Store and some other apps.

To access picture-in-picture mode, open a compatible video in Safari and click the icon in the playback controls toolbar that resembles two rectangles. This will pop out the video in a small, resizable window that you can move around the screen by dragging its corner. You can also hold down the Command key while dragging the window to your desired position.

When you hover your cursor over the video window, you'll see controls to pause or play the video, exit picture-in-picture mode, or close the window entirely. However, to fast-forward or rewind through the video, you'll need to use the playback controls on the video's page in the main Safari window.

The television audience has grown increasingly dispersed due to the rise of streaming, making it a rare event for a show to attract more than 20 million viewers. Despite this trend, live broadcasts of major sporting events and awards shows continue to draw large crowds. The interview segment featuring Ms. Clifford proved to be a major draw, surpassing the viewership of both the Grammys and Golden Globes. The "60 Minutes" episode outperformed the usual editions of NBC's "Sunday Night Football," which averaged 18 million viewers, and nearly matched the viewership of ABC's Academy Awards broadcast last month, which had 26.5 million viewers. The highly anticipated segment on Ms. Clifford sparked viewing parties across the country. The broadcast also outperformed recent "60 Minutes" breakout episodes, including the El Chapo-focused interview with Sean Penn and Lesley Stahl's sit-down with Mr. Trump and his family.

Dan Schneider, Nickelodeon's most successful producer over the past two decades, is ending his partnership with the cable channel. As a former child actor who appeared in "Head of the Class" and "Better Off Dead", Schneider has created numerous hit shows for Nickelodeon, including "iCarly", "Drake & Josh", and "Kenan & Kel". Dubbed the "Norman Lear of children's television" by The New York Times, Schneider's production company, Schneider's Bakery, is also behind Nickelodeon's current top-rated show, "Henry Danger". However, one of his shows, "Game Shakers", was recently discontinued. Nickelodeon and Schneider, 52, have agreed not to renew their current deal after "many conversations about future directions and opportunities". The statement explained that since several Schneider's Bakery projects are nearing completion, both parties have decided that this is a natural time to explore new opportunities and projects.

"I've installed ad-blocking software on my computer, but I still see ads on some pages. This is because browser utilities like AdBlock or AdBlock Plus may still display less-intrusive ads from approved companies. AdBlock Plus makes money by allowing these ads to pass through its filters, aiming to balance web users' needs with websites' advertising revenue needs.

"Acceptable" ads don't use animation and don't interrupt the reader's experience. Even if your ad-blocker program allows non-intrusive ads by default, you can disable this feature in the program's settings. If you frequently visit a site and find its advertising acceptable, consider allowing its ads through your filter or adding the site to the ad-blocking program's white list.

To "white-list" a site means to make an exception for it in your ad-blocking program, allowing advertising to appear. While some ads can be distracting, excessive, or laden with malware, most sites run ads to sustain themselves. Some sites have implemented ad-blocker detection tools and will prevent your browser from loading the page unless you white-list the site. Others may ask you to white-list them in exchange for displaying minimal advertising.

If you need to white-list a site, click the ad-blocker icon in the browser's toolbar and look for the option to pause or disable the current filtering. The program's toolbar menu may display a list of sites you have white-listed, along with controls for fine-tuning your ad filters."

The Atlantic magazine has severed its ties with conservative writer Kevin D. Williamson, whose hiring in March sparked a heated online debate about acceptable views in mainstream publications. The controversy centered on Williamson's extreme stance on abortion, which he advocates should be punished as premeditated homicide, potentially with the death penalty. This hardline view was initially expressed in a 2014 Twitter exchange and ultimately led to his departure from the magazine. Initially, Editor-in-Chief Jeffrey Goldberg defended Williamson, stating he didn't want to judge individuals based on their worst tweets or isolated statements. However, Goldberg later reversed his stance, citing a podcast episode from the same month in which Williamson elaborated on his anti-abortion views, which he deemed more than just trollish.

A juvenile sperm whale, measuring 33 feet in length and weighing 13,000 pounds, was discovered on a beach in Cape Palos, Spain, in February, likely due to its inability to digest the massive amount of plastic waste it had ingested. The underweight whale, still growing, was an unusual case, as adult sperm whales typically reach up to 120,000 pounds. A necropsy revealed that the whale's digestive system was severely clogged with 64 pounds of trash, including plastic bags, ropes, and a plastic drum, which it was unable to digest or pass through its system. This led to severe inflammation, ultimately causing the whale's decline and death. Sperm whales, which dive to great depths to hunt squid, often linger near the surface, making them vulnerable to ingesting floating debris that may be mistaken for food. Unfortunately, ocean pollution has devastating effects on wildlife, particularly in areas where buoyant debris accumulates in "islands" of trash that float above or just below the surface. The Great Pacific Garbage Patch is estimated to contain at least 87,000 tons of plastic. As plastic pollution continues to grow, some scientists believe it may have a greater impact on animal populations than climate change. In 2008, two whales were found on a beach in Northern California with bags and netting in their stomachs, likely discarded by fishermen. One whale's stomach had ruptured, and the other, which had consumed over 160 pounds of trash, likely starved to death as the garbage obstructed its stomach. The authorities in Murcia have released the results of a necropsy conducted by the El Valle Wildlife Recovery Center as part of a campaign to raise awareness about the impact of plastic and trash in the coastal region's waters. Volunteers are working to clean up local beaches and are urging the public to be more mindful of their plastic waste disposal. It is crucial that we address this issue through both cleanup efforts and education, ensuring our citizens are aware of the importance of protecting our environment.

A study has revealed that sea turtles use the Earth's magnetic fields to navigate back to their birthplace, a journey that can span multiple decades. Researchers analyzed loggerhead turtle genetics and found that the turtles swim in a large loop from their nesting grounds in North Carolina and Florida to North Africa before returning to nest within a 40-50 mile radius of their birthplace. The study suggests that turtles imprint the unique magnetic signature of their home beach, a process known as geomagnetic imprinting. According to Dr. Kenneth Lohmann, this knowledge is crucial for restoring sea turtle populations to areas where they once thrived before being driven to extinction. He also notes that similar principles may apply to restoring salmon and other fish populations to their natural habitats, as many birds and fish rely on magnetic fields for navigation.

Facebook has replaced its US head of policy, Erin Egan, amidst intense regulatory and legislative scrutiny. Egan, who led policy for two years and served as chief privacy officer, was responsible for lobbying and government relations. Kevin Martin, a former FCC chairman, will temporarily assume her duties, overseeing mobile and global access policy. While Egan relinquishes her role as head of policy, she will continue as chief privacy officer, focusing on global privacy policies. She will collaborate with product teams to rebuild trust in user information handling, a Facebook spokesperson stated.

I'm hesitant to erase my beloved e-books from my Nook device, yet I'm intrigued by what occurs to my digital library when my device runs out of storage or becomes obsolete. The Nook series, akin to its Amazon Kindle counterpart, stores digital book purchases online. Even if I delete or archive a title, I can always download and read it again from the cloud backup. I can also access my books in my web browser for a larger screen experience.

To eliminate books from my Nook, the process differs depending on the model, but I can find specific guidelines on the Barnes & Noble support pages. On my current Nook Tablet, I can access the Nook Library app, select the book I want to archive, and press my finger to select Remove. Choosing the Delete From Account option will permanently remove the book from my collection.

To archive multiple books simultaneously, I can navigate to the Library's Grid view screen, tap the three-dot menu icon, and select Manage Storage. From there, I can remove books from my list. I can also view all my Nook books by choosing Archive from the same corner menu. Titles that are no longer physically on my device will be marked with a cloud-download arrow on the cover.

Researchers at Cornell University and other institutions are developing a novel approach to track gypsy moth spores through indirect genetic sampling, enhancing predictions of moth damage. A single cloud of spores can disperse over 40 miles or more from its source, according to a 2017 study. The gypsy moth is the adult stage of a caterpillar species introduced from France in 1869, posing a significant threat to tree canopies. The gypsy moth's feeding habits are more destructive to trees than those of native tent caterpillars, which it resembles. A fungus targeting gypsy moths was first detected in the Northeast in 1989, with efforts to introduce it as a biological control measure dating back to 1910. In 2000, a coordinated program was launched by 11 states and the US Forest Service to combat the gypsy moth infestation. While the program has not halted the spread of the moths, it has significantly slowed their advance. The Cornell researchers aim to harness the natural fungal predator to control the gypsy moth population and reduce reliance on insecticides.

Record a video of your iPhone 7 screen using the built-in Screen Recording tool. To enable this feature, navigate to your iPhone's home screen, open Settings, and then tap Control Center. Tap Customize Controls, add Screen Recording by tapping the green plus button, and scroll down to More Controls. Once added, a circular "record" button will appear in Control Center when you swipe up from the bottom of the screen. To start recording, swipe up to open Control Center and press the Screen Recording button. To include audio, press the button until a menu appears with the Microphone Audio option, then select it.

Lachlan Murdoch, 46, has been named CEO and chairman of the Murdoch family's television company, a move widely anticipated. This appointment cements Lachlan's status as his father Rupert Murdoch's successor, with Rupert, 87, becoming co-chairman. The news release from 21st Century Fox, which plans to sell a significant portion of its assets to Disney, did not mention Lachlan's younger brother James, 45, who currently leads the company. James is expected to pursue a new venture, possibly focusing on digital media investments. The management changes were announced as part of the proposed sale, pending shareholder and regulatory approval. However, Comcast is attempting to disrupt the deal with a hostile bid. Regardless of the outcome, the sale will involve the transfer of 21st Century Fox's movie studio, its stake in Hulu, cable networks, and interests in overseas TV providers.

A long-standing feud between two major media companies persists, with no signs of abating. CBS Corporation has taken a bold step by amending its lawsuit against its parent company, escalating the power struggle between CEO Leslie Moonves and controlling shareholder Shari Redstone. The move is part of a series of efforts by CBS to prevent a merger with its corporate sibling, Viacom, which Redstone, president of National Amusements, is pushing for. The amended complaint, filed in Delaware Chancery Court, asserts the independence of CBS's board and seeks a court determination on the validity of a recent vote. The lawsuit also accuses Redstone of attempting to coerce a merger between CBS and Viacom, which it claims would not be in the best interests of CBS and its shareholders. Redstone has expressed support for a merger, but maintains she has no intention of forcing one.

Is there a straightforward way to convert an online article's text into a PDF file, excluding ads, so I can read it offline or print it more conveniently from my computer without copying and pasting the text? If your browser has a "reader mode" that temporarily removes ads and distractions, you can create a simple PDF file without additional software. To do this, switch to reader mode when you find an article you want to save, then use the PDF-saving function in the Print box on your Windows PC or Mac to create a copy of the article in a new file. Note that some websites may not support reader modes, but many do. For articles spanning multiple pages, look for a "read on one page" or "Read More" button that displays the full text on one screen, allowing you to save the entire article in a single PDF file.

HBO is developing a pilot episode for one of its five "Game of Thrones" prequels, which explores the origins of the White Walkers thousands of years before the original series. The show delves into the world's decline from a golden age of heroes to its darkest hour, uncovering the true origins of the White Walkers and other mysteries. George R.R. Martin co-created the story with Jane Goldman, who wrote the teleplay and will serve as showrunner for the pilot.

In ancient Mesoamerica, stretching from central Mexico to Central America, turquoise was a highly valued gemstone due to its striking blue and green hues. The Aztecs and Mixtecs utilized the mineral to craft armbands, nose plugs, and decorative handles for sacrificial knives, as well as intricate mosaics of warriors and fearsome statues of double-headed serpents. For over a century, archaeologists have endeavored to uncover the origins of the turquoise used in these stunning pieces of art and jewelry. Despite finding limited evidence of turquoise mining in Mesoamerica, some researchers have proposed that the turquoise artifacts in the region resulted from a long-distance trade exchange with ancient civilizations in the American Southwest, where turquoise mines have been discovered. However, a recent geochemical analysis of Aztec and Mixtec turquoise has revealed that the mineral did not originate in the American Southwest, but rather in Mesoamerica itself. This finding, published in the journal Science Advances, also challenges the notion that there was extensive cultural exchange between Mesoamerican and Southwest American societies before the Spanish invasion in the 1500s.

For years, I relied on Picasa for editing and printing my photos, finding it an intuitive program to use. However, Google's discontinuation of Picasa support has left me seeking an alternative. After Picasa's retirement from further development in 2016, the desktop photo-editing program lost its ability to upload, download, and manage online albums. While similar programs exist, they may not offer the same level of editing tools and online album-sharing capabilities as Picasa. To find a suitable replacement, identify the features you used most frequently and look for a program that matches those capabilities. Google Photos, which replaced Picasa in Google's free software lineup, might be the simplest option for your files, as your Picasa Web Albums are likely already stored there. Simply log in at photos.google.com using the same Google Account name and password. Google Photos allows you to back up your computer's pictures to online server space and order printed photo books. However, some users may find the photo-editing tools less comprehensive than those offered in Picasa.

Every week, our technology team at The New York Times reviews the latest news, providing in-depth analysis and a dash of humor on the most significant tech industry developments. Hi, I'm Jack Nicas, a technology reporter based in San Francisco. We're shaking things up with a new format, where a different correspondent will deliver this newsletter each week. I'm kicking things off, still reeling from my birthday celebrations in Mexico. As tech journalists, we'll strive to bring our unique perspectives and a touch of humor to our coverage. This week, we'll dive into the controversy surrounding the Trump administration's halted policy of separating immigrant children from their parents at the border. The story has dominated headlines, seeping into nearly every area of coverage, including tech. As we've seen over the past two years, tech companies have found themselves drawn into political debates they've long sought to avoid. This week, my colleague Sheera Frenkel reported that over 100 Microsoft employees signed a letter urging the company to halt business with Immigration and Customs Enforcement, the federal agency responsible for separating families at the border. Executives from Apple, Google, Facebook, and other tech giants also publicly condemned the policy.

Over the past four years, Facebook has been developing solar-powered drones with large wingspans, aiming to provide internet access to those without connectivity. To attract new users, Facebook requires innovative solutions, given its vast user base. However, the ambitious project unexpectedly came to a halt on Wednesday. Facebook announced it would no longer build the drones, abandoning its original goal of expanding internet access. Instead, the company will rely on other companies to develop aircraft. A manufacturing plant in western England, where the drones were being produced, will be closed. Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook's co-founder and CEO, envisioned solar-powered drones flying for months without landing, 60,000 feet above remote areas. The massive aircraft filled a warehouse but weighed as much as a grand piano. Following a successful test flight in 2016, Zuckerberg hailed the project as "something that's never been done before." Unfortunately, the drone initiative, known as Project Aquila, faced several setbacks, including a crash landing and broken wing. Project Aquila was part of Facebook's Internet.org initiative to expand internet access in underdeveloped areas, a controversial effort criticized by some as a ploy to attract new users.

Google Maps provides a feature to calculate the straight-line distance between two points, often referred to as "as the crow flies". This feature differs from driving directions, which consider roads, traffic, detours, and other factors. To access this feature, right-click on the starting point or city and select "Measure distance" in a desktop web browser. Click on the second point to display the direct distance in miles and kilometers. You can add more points by clicking elsewhere on the map, delete a point by clicking on it, or move measurement points by dragging them. Once complete, click the X to finish the measurement.

Barnes & Noble announced the termination of CEO Demos Parneros on Tuesday, citing a policy violation without specifying which policies were breached. The company emphasized that the decision was unrelated to financial reporting, policies, or practices, nor was it related to potential fraud. As a result, Parneros will not receive a severance package and has been removed from the board of directors. This marks the fourth time in five years that Barnes & Noble's CEO has departed. Parneros held the CEO position for just over a year, having previously served as chief operating officer before being promoted to replace Ronald Boire, who had a similar brief tenure as CEO before being ousted in August 2016 due to concerns about his fit with the company.

Last week, Showtime generated significant buzz on social media by posting a teaser on YouTube announcing the upcoming release of what it claims is the most dangerous show in television history. On Monday, the network revealed more details: Sacha Baron Cohen is returning to television with a seven-episode series, Who Is America?, which will premiere on Sunday. The series marks Baron Cohen's first starring role on TV since 2004, when HBO aired the final season of Da Ali G Show. Who Is America? has been in development for over a year. The show's format appears consistent with Baron Cohen's previous work, blurring the line between satire and reporting through his disguises and interviews with unwitting subjects. On Sunday, Baron Cohen's Twitter account linked to a trailer that began with the phrase, Imagine if Sacha Baron Cohen had been undercover, secretly filming a new show for a year. The trailer showed a snippet of former Vice President Dick Cheney signing what Baron Cohen's new character called his waterboard kit. The video has been viewed over one million times.

Since its 2012 launch, Wing has faced challenges refining its technology, prompting a complete redesign. Despite progress, recent advancements suggest the team remains satisfied with its current state. However, technical hurdles persist, including drone delivery in urban areas, and regulatory obstacles may prove even more formidable. The Federal Aviation Administration is gradually approving drone delivery tests in the US, including a forthcoming pilot program with Wing in Virginia. To capitalize on regulatory requirements, Wing is developing software enabling unmanned aircraft to navigate the skies, essentially creating an automated air traffic control system for drones. Meanwhile, Alphabet's Loon unit is building high-altitude balloons to deliver internet connections to rural or disaster-stricken areas. These massive balloons, operating at an altitude of around 13 miles above ground, use wind currents to cluster around areas with poor connectivity. Loon collaborates with local telecommunications companies to enhance cell service on the ground, acting as a temporary, floating cell tower. Loon, which originated in 2011 within X, has since traveled over 18 million miles, providing internet connectivity from Brazil to New Zealand. Last year, Loon delivered connections to Peru following floods and Puerto Rico after Hurricane Maria.

"I'm looking for a simple way to convert hundreds of TIFF photos to JPG at once. Fortunately, you can convert a large collection of images from one format to another in a single step, just like renaming multiple photos. TIFF files, commonly used in print production, are typically larger than JPG files, which are more compressed and suitable for web use. Most image-editing software, such as Adobe Photoshop, offer commands to convert TIFF to JPG, and the program's help guide should provide specific conversion instructions. If you don't use photo-management software, there are affordable utility programs available. You can find these programs on the Mac and Windows app stores, which offer various options for converting file formats, resizing, and optimizing images in bulk. When selecting a program, read the reviews and ensure it meets your specific needs."

Waymo, a Google subsidiary, is streamlining daily commutes. By partnering with five businesses, including Walmart, Avis, and AutoNation, Waymo is introducing self-driving rides in Phoenix. This collaboration showcases Waymo's ambition to seamlessly integrate its technology into daily routines by transporting individuals between their homes, local businesses, and nearby destinations. Under its partnership with Walmart, customers purchasing groceries online can request a Waymo vehicle to transport them to a store to collect their orders. This new service, launching this week, is the latest effort by Walmart to gain a competitive advantage in the grocery market, building on its personal shopper program and expanded online delivery service.

"The accelerometer, a ubiquitous sensor in devices such as phones, fitness trackers, and smartwatches, enables screen rotation. By measuring velocity changes, the sensor allows software to detect how the device is being held and adjust the screen orientation accordingly. This functionality enables automatic screen rotation when switching from browsing to watching a wide-screen video. The accelerometer's motion-sensing capabilities also support features like augmented-reality apps, games, and navigation tools that track speed and direction."

Jake Tapper, the seasoned CNN anchor, abruptly cut off a guest to apologize, flashing a lopsided grin as he announced, "We have some breaking news." The subsequent hour-long broadcast was a frenetic mix of unexpected developments, with journalists scrambling to keep pace with the unfolding drama that rivaled the most unpredictable plot twists from "House of Cards." On Tuesday, a stunning double whammy struck the news: Michael D. Cohen, President Trump's longtime lawyer, pleaded guilty in a Manhattan courtroom, while Paul Manafort, Trump's former campaign manager, was convicted of eight counts of fraud in a Virginia trial.
